docs.lead_paragraph: The president said what he heard from voters Tuesday was to “get stuff done,” and he pointed out areas where he thinks agreement could be reached.
docs.abstract: Editorial notes Pres Obama's post-election news conference in which he refused to submit to Republican narrative that his presidency effectively ended with midterm elections; supports Obama's vow to not let Republicans gut health care law; observes that both Obama and new Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell outlined areas where they hope to find common ground.
docs.snippet: The president said what he heard from voters Tuesday was to “get stuff done,” and he pointed out areas where he thinks agreement could be reached.

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers debate how to interpret the huge Republican victories on Election Day, and what Democrats should have done differently.

headline.main: The Messages of the Midterm Election
headline.print_headline: The Messages of the Midterm Election

docs.snippet: Readers debate how to interpret the huge Republican victories on Election Day, and what Democrats should have done differently.

docs.lead_paragraph: Issues expected to get a new look include a corporate tax overhaul, environmental and financial regulation, trade deals and the Keystone oil pipeline.

headline.main: Business Leaders Cautiously Expect G.O.P. Win to Open Some Doors
headline.print_headline: G.O.P Win Is Expected to Open Some Doors

docs.abstract: Experts on Wall Street and political veterans say actual legislative agenda of new Republican majorities in both houses of Congress will be limited, despite plenty of public talk of more aggressive action on issues like corporate taxation and financial regulation.
docs.snippet: Issues expected to get a new look include a corporate tax overhaul, environmental and financial regulation, trade deals and the Keystone oil pipeline.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican surge in Tuesday's U.S. elections carried Arkansas along with it, threatening to sweep away a bipartisan health insurance plan in the state that is also being studied by other states as an alternative to Obamacare.

docs.lead_paragraph: The election of a new Texas governor usually means the arrival of another Lone Star archetype — boots-wearing, backslapping and big on swagger about the state's outsized importance.

docs.lead_paragraph: State capitols across the country will be more Republican than at any point since the Roaring '20s when victorious legislators and governors take office next year. That could result in lower taxes and perhaps fewer dollars flowing to social safety net programs.

headline.main: Election Brings New GOP Power to State Capitols
headline.print_headline: Election Brings New GOP Power to State Capitols

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama said on Wednesday he was open to "responsible" changes to his signature healthcare law that might be proposed by congressional Republicans, but would not accept revisions that undermine the reforms.

headline.print_headline: Obama Says Open to 'Responsible' Changes to Signature Health Law

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. services firms expanded more slowly in October, but the pace of growth was still healthy. Hiring also rose to the fastest pace in more than nine years.

docs.abstract: More than a third of people voting for a Republican House candidate said they were unhappy or even angry at the Republican leaders in Congress.
